thread.title: What you need to know about the latest Brexit agreements

author: leicestermercury
title: What you need to know about the latest Brexit agreements
text:
What you need to know about the latest Brexit agreements Announcements were made this morning     
Theresa May has clinched an agreement to allow Brexit negotiations to move forward. 
After overnight talks in Brussels the PM sealed the deal on three key issues. 
These were Northern Ireland, the rights of 3.2million EU citizens living in the UK and the divorce bill. 
That means, if agreed by 27 EU leaders, Britain can finally move on to start talking about its trade with the Continent after March 2019. 
The PM said: “It hasn't been easy for either side.” 
Mr Juncker added: "Today's result is, of course, a compromise". 
So what does the full, very complicated 15-page document say in plain English and where has she compromised? Here's a summary from the Mirror Online . EU Commission handout picture showing British Prime Minister Theresa May (left) and EU President Jean-Claude Juncker (Image: Etienne Ansotte/EU/PA Wire) Northern Ireland border 
This is about finding an arrangement for Northern Ireland that doesn't cut it off from either the Republic - which is part of the EU - or the rest of the UK. 
This was a key sticking point with the DUP. 
The agreement commits to guarantee no hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic - whatever happens. Read More These are your rights if you can't get into work due to the snow 
But at the same time, Northern Ireland will get unfettered access to the internal UK market - even though the UK is leaving the EU's single market and customs union. 
The UK wants to secure Northern Ireland's status without any special treatment through an overall EU-UK deal later in the process. 
If that's not possible, however, Northern Ireland will get "full alignment" with some current EU rules it shares with the Republic. Citizens' rights 
This is about ensuring the 3.2million EU citizens in Britain, and 1.2million Brits living in the other 27 EU nations, can stay after Brexit. Theresa May refused to give a firm promise until she had one for UK citizens. 
Britain and the EU have now agreed a reciprocal deal, so everything that applies to Britain will apply to the other 27 countries too. 
Mrs May's plan to force EU citizens to apply for "settled status" appears to be intact - she wanted to let people apply after they've been in Britain for five years. Read More Upgraded weather warning of heavy snow issued for Sunday in Leicestershire 
But the arrangements must be "transparent, smooth and streamlined", the deal says. 
People who've settled in Britain can now leave for up to five years without losing their settlement rights. 
Residence documents must be issued either free of charge, or no more expensive than similar documents would be for UK nationals. EU Commission handout picture showing British Prime Minister Theresa May and EU President Jean-Claude Juncker at a press conference (Image: Etienne Ansotte/EU/PA Wire) 
A "proportionate approach" will be taken to those who "miss the deadline with good reason". 
People who already have UK residence documents issued under EU law must have them converted to the new status free of charge - with only a security and background check. 
Benefits and healthcare arrangements will continue as they are now for people living in a country under the agreement before 29 March 2019. Divorce bill 
This is about agreeing how much Britain should continue pay in the EU before (and after) it leaves. 
"We've now agreed a settlement that is fair to the British taxpayer," said Theresa May. "We will be able to invest more in our priorities at home, such as housing, schools and the NHS." Read More 
But one thing's for sure - it won't be £350million a week. 
Downing Street said the bill would be 40 to 45billion Euros - or £35billion to £39billion. 
There is no one figure in the document, but the "methodology" is now agreed. 
Britain will carry on paying in to the EU budget in 2019 and 2020 "as if it had remained in the EU", even though it leaves in March 2019. Read More
